title: How to Make a LEGO Stop Motion

steps.headline: Get a suitable camera.
steps.description: The camera must be able to take good quality images.

steps.headline: Test drive the camera first.
steps.description: It's important to be comfortable with how it works, and which of its features are likely to produce the effects you're after. If you haven't read the manual yet, now is the perfect time to do so.

steps.headline: Practice working with a tripod.
steps.description: This is essential, as it makes for perfectly still shots.

steps.headline: Keep the story simple.
steps.description: The longer the story, the longer you will be taking images, so keep it very short to begin with. For example, a short sketch could be about a mini-figure attacking or robbing another mini-figure and another one coming to the rescue. Or, it could be about one mini-figure pranking another. Or, have a bunch of mini-figures sitting around a table having coffee and talking about life.

steps.headline: Write the sketch out.
steps.description: Include dialog if relevant. All of this will make it much easier for you, as you'll know what props you need, how involved the whole scene will be and what dialog you want to add later (if any).

steps.headline: Start with a Lego base plate.
steps.description: The base plate is a large square with pegs that allow figures and blocks to be attached to it. Choose the color according to the story theme, for example, green for grass, grey for a factory or office floor, yellow for a party, etc.

steps.headline: Ensure that the base plate cannot move.
steps.description: Place pieces of rolled up tape or two-sided tape underneath the base plate. Then press the base plate down firmly on the surface where you intend to do the filming from. It's a really good idea to place the set where it won't be disturbed for several days. That way, you can take breaks and come back to the filming later, when you feel refreshed.

steps.headline: Find the mini-figures and Lego pieces you need.
steps.description: Include animals, flowers, trees, etc. If you need to have buildings, vehicles, trees, etc., sketch a design, as this will help you to know where everything should go.

steps.headline: Make the set.
steps.description: Build the design onto the base plate set, as per your sketch or ideas. Check that all the supporting pieces are firmly in place and can't be knocked over easily.

steps.headline: Place the camera on the tripod.
steps.description: Position the figures where they're meant to be.

steps.headline: Move the Lego person slowly.
steps.description: The more frames you take, the better the final movie will be, so only move a fraction each time. Sure, it's painful but good art requires effort. It is also possible to move the set slightly. Experiment a little.

steps.headline: Continue taking shots until the whole scene is done.
Use your film editing program on your computer or digital device.
steps.description: Transfer the photos and piece the movie together.

steps.headline: Add dialog boxes if relevant.
steps.description: Or, simply print comments, etc. along the base of the movie.

steps.headline: Watch it all the way through.
steps.description: If you're happy with the end result, upload it to YouTube.

text: Steps Get a suitable camera. The camera must be able to take good quality images. Test drive the camera first. It's important to be comfortable with how it works, and which of its features are likely to produce the effects you're after. If you haven't read the manual yet, now is the perfect time to do so. Practice working with a tripod. This is essential, as it makes for perfectly still shots. Developing a story Keep the story simple. The longer the story, the longer you will be taking images, so keep it very short to begin with. For example, a short sketch could be about a mini-figure attacking or robbing another mini-figure and another one coming to the rescue. Or, it could be about one mini-figure pranking another. Or, have a bunch of mini-figures sitting around a table having coffee and talking about life. Write the sketch out. Include dialog if relevant. All of this will make it much easier for you, as you'll know what props you need, how involved the whole scene will be and what dialog you want to add later (if any). Preparing the Lego pieces Start with a Lego base plate. The base plate is a large square with pegs that allow figures and blocks to be attached to it. Choose the color according to the story theme, for example, green for grass, grey for a factory or office floor, yellow for a party, etc. Ensure that the base plate cannot move. Place pieces of rolled up tape or two-sided tape underneath the base plate. Then press the base plate down firmly on the surface where you intend to do the filming from. It's a really good idea to place the set where it won't be disturbed for several days. That way, you can take breaks and come back to the filming later, when you feel refreshed. Find the mini-figures and Lego pieces you need. Include animals, flowers, trees, etc. If you need to have buildings, vehicles, trees, etc., sketch a design, as this will help you to know where everything should go. Make the set. Build the design onto the base plate set, as per your sketch or ideas. Check that all the supporting pieces are firmly in place and can't be knocked over easily. Filming the stop motion Place the camera on the tripod. Position the figures where they're meant to be. Take the first photo.  Move the Lego person slowly. The more frames you take, the better the final movie will be, so only move a fraction each time. Sure, it's painful but good art requires effort. It is also possible to move the set slightly. Experiment a little. Continue taking shots until the whole scene is done.  Editing the stop motion Use your film editing program on your computer or digital device. Transfer the photos and piece the movie together. Add dialog boxes if relevant. Or, simply print comments, etc. along the base of the movie. Watch it all the way through. If you're happy with the end result, upload it to YouTube.
